title: Relationship Mastery
subtitle: The complete curriculum for conscious partnership
description: This is not a course you complete in a weekend. It's an 8-12 week practicum that requires real engagement — with the material, with yourself, and with your relationships. Each module combines deep understanding with structured practice. You will complete real-world exercises, document your practice, and demonstrate skill development. The certificate means you've done the work, not just consumed the content.

modules.title: Your Pattern in High Definition

modules.title: The Anatomy of Your Fights

modules.title: The Art of Repair
modules.description: Turning rupture into deepening — the skill that predicts relationship success

modules.title: Boundaries That Serve Love

modules.title: Integration and Assessment
modules.description: Demonstrating what you've learned — through reflection, documentation, and self-assessment

whatYouLearn: Map your specific relational patterns with precision — not general attachment styles, YOUR patterns
Regulate your nervous system during relationship activation — demonstrated through practice logs
Communicate difficult truths without violence or withdrawal — through structured practice
Navigate conflict without the Four Horsemen — documented through conflict analysis
Initiate and complete repair after rupture — with evidence of real practice
Set and hold boundaries that protect without isolating — tested in real situations
Maintain attraction and polarity over time — through ongoing practice
requirements: Currently in a relationship or actively dating (required for practice exercises)
Minimum 8 weeks to complete — cannot rush through
Willingness to complete structured practice exercises and document results
Journal or document for tracking practice
Partner awareness recommended for some exercises

components.name: Knowledge Assessment
components.description: Multiple choice and short answer questions testing understanding

questions.question: A partner says 'You're always criticizing me.' You notice defensiveness rising. What is the FIRST thing to do?
options: Explain why the criticism was justified
Apologize immediately to end the conflict
Recognize and regulate your own nervous system activation before responding
Point out times they've criticized you

questions.question: You notice you're attracted to someone who creates anxiety in you — hot then cold, unpredictable. This is likely:
options: True love that's worth fighting for
Your nervous system mistaking anxiety activation for passion
Evidence they're playing hard to get
Normal early relationship dynamics

questions.question: During a fight, your heart rate exceeds 100 BPM and you can't think clearly. You should:
options: Push through and finish the conversation
Say 'I need 20-30 minutes to calm down, then I want to continue this conversation' and self-regulate
Agree with whatever they're saying to end the conflict
Leave without explanation

questions.question: Your partner did something that hurt you. A repair conversation should include:
options: A detailed list of everything they've done wrong
Acknowledgment of impact, taking responsibility where appropriate, and intentional reconnection
Waiting until they apologize first
Pretending it didn't happen to keep the peace

questions.question: You want more physical affection but feel awkward asking. The best approach is:
options: Drop hints and hope they pick up on it
Withhold affection until they give more first
State your need directly: 'I'd love more physical affection. Can we talk about that?'
Accept that they're just not affectionate

questions.question: A 'boundary' in relationship is:
options: A rule you impose on your partner's behavior
A statement of what you will and won't accept, with consequences you control
A threat to leave if they don't change
Something only needed in unhealthy relationships

questions.question: Polarity in a relationship refers to:
options: One partner being dominant and one submissive
The dynamic tension between different energies that creates attraction
Being opposites in personality
Disagreeing frequently

questions.question: Research shows that 69% of relationship conflicts are 'perpetual' — never fully resolved. This means:
options: Most relationships are doomed to fail
You should learn to dialogue about these issues without gridlock, rather than trying to solve them
You should avoid discussing these issues
You need to find a more compatible partner

questions.question: Your partner often withdraws during conflict (stonewalls). The most effective response is:
options: Pursue them more intensely to resolve the issue
Stonewall back to show them how it feels
Recognize they may be flooded, give space, and agree on when to return to the conversation
Interpret their withdrawal as not caring about the relationship

questions.question: 'Earned secure attachment' means:
options: You found a partner who makes you feel secure
You developed secure attachment through conscious work despite insecure early experiences
You were always secure but didn't realize it
You earned your partner's trust through good behavior

questions.question: What predicts relationship success better than compatibility, chemistry, or absence of conflict?
options: Similar backgrounds and values
The ability to repair after conflict
Never fighting
Intense initial attraction

questions.question: You notice you often pick apart your partner's flaws when they get close to you. This is likely:
options: Evidence you're with the wrong person
A deactivating strategy of avoidant attachment — creating distance when intimacy threatens
Healthy discernment
Their fault for having flaws
